newsitem.title: GERMANY: Boeing to compensate for Dominican crash - lawyer.
newsitem.headline: Boeing to compensate for Dominican crash - lawyer.

text.p: A lawyer representing 70 relatives of German tourists who died in a Boeing 757 plane crash in the Caribbean last year said on Saturday that Boeing Co. was prepared to pay compensation.

Lawyer Heiko Van Schyndel told Reuters the U.S aircraft manufacturer wanted to avoid a law suit by the victims' families after a report showed the probable cause to be the crew's confusion over the aircraft's system.

"Boeing recognized the claims of the relatives at the beginning of this month and said it was prepared to pay compensation," said Van Schyndel who works for a law firm in Berlin representing 70 relatives of victims.
In Seattle, Boeing Co. spokesman John Dern said the plane company was involved in discussions with the representatives of the victims' families, but had not reached any settlement.
"Because the discussions are on-going, it is inappropriate for me to go into specifics," he told Reuters. "We haven't reached any conclusions yet."
Dern would not comment on the lawyer's version that Boeing had set aside $18 million. "I just can't go into that."

The 757 leased to the Dominican airline Alas Nacionales by Turkish carrier Birgenair plunged into the sea on Feb. 9 shortly after taking off from the Dominican resort of Puerto Plata. All 189 people on board, mostly German tourists, died.
Van Schyndel said that victims' lawyers would meet Boeing's lawyers at the company headquarters in Seattle in June to discuss the details of the payments.

"Boeing wants to prevent a law suit against them to claim for maintenance and compensation for personal suffering. We said we would not rule out filing a suit if we do not reach an agreement with them," Van Schyndel said.
"Boeing wants to avoid the negative publicity," he said.
Spiegel news magazine reported that Boeing was prepared to pay relatives compensation in cases where maintenance was required, for example, to children who lost their parents.
An official report last October year said the plane crash off the Dominican Republic was probably due to human error.

In the report, the Dominican office of Civil Aviation and the U.S. National Transportation Safety Board said the probable cause of the crash was the crew's "confusion and lack of knowledge" of the aircraft's systems.
Spiegel said Boeing had since made amendments to the instructions in the 757's cockpit handbook for pilots.
